title: Solving Linear Equations
description: Solve for x: 3x + 7 = 22

title: Quadratic Formula Application
description: Use the quadratic formula to solve: x² - 6x + 9 = 0
solution:
Using the quadratic formula: x = (-b ± √(b² - 4ac)) / 2a
Here a = 1, b = -6, c = 9
x = (6 ± √(36 - 36)) / 2 = 6/2 = 3
The equation has one repeated root: x = 3

title: System of Linear Equations
description:
Solve the system using elimination method:
2x + 3y = 11
4x - y = 13
solution:
Multiply first equation by 2: 4x + 6y = 22
Subtract second equation: (4x + 6y) - (4x - y) = 22 - 13
7y = 9, so y = 9/7
Substitute back: 2x + 3(9/7) = 11
2x = 11 - 27/7 = 50/7
x = 25/7
Solution: x = 25/7, y = 9/7

title: Polynomial Factoring
description: Factor completely: x³ - 8x² + 16x
solution:
x³ - 8x² + 16x = x(x² - 8x + 16) = x(x - 4)²
The completely factored form is x(x - 4)²

title: Basic Derivative
description: Find the derivative of f(x) = 3x⁴ - 2x³ + 5x - 7
solution:
Using the power rule d/dx[xⁿ] = nxⁿ⁻¹:
f'(x) = 12x³ - 6x² + 5

title: Chain Rule Application
description: Find the derivative of f(x) = (2x³ + 1)⁵
solution:
Using chain rule: d/dx[g(h(x))] = g'(h(x)) · h'(x)
Let u = 2x³ + 1, then f(x) = u⁵
f'(x) = 5u⁴ · (6x²) = 5(2x³ + 1)⁴ · 6x² = 30x²(2x³ + 1)⁴

title: Integration by Substitution
description: Evaluate the integral: ∫ 6x(3x² + 1)² dx
solution:
Let u = 3x² + 1, then du = 6x dx
∫ 6x(3x² + 1)² dx = ∫ u² du = u³/3 + C = (3x² + 1)³/3 + C

title: Limits at Infinity
description: Find the limit: lim(x→∞) (2x³ - 5x² + 1)/(x³ + 3x - 2)
solution:
Divide numerator and denominator by x³:
lim(x→∞) (2 - 5/x + 1/x³)/(1 + 3/x² - 2/x³) = 2/1 = 2
The limit is 2.

title: Area of Triangle
description: Find the area of a triangle with vertices at (0,0), (4,0), and (2,3)
solution:
Using the coordinate formula: Area = ½|x₁(y₂ - y₃) + x₂(y₃ - y₁) + x₃(y₁ - y₂)|
Area = ½|0(0 - 3) + 4(3 - 0) + 2(0 - 0)| = ½|0 + 12 + 0| = 6 square units

title: Circle Equation
description: Find the equation of a circle with center (-2, 3) and radius 5
solution:
The standard form of a circle is (x - h)² + (y - k)² = r²
where (h, k) is the center and r is the radius.
(x - (-2))² + (y - 3)² = 5²
(x + 2)² + (y - 3)² = 25

title: Pythagorean Theorem
description: A right triangle has legs of length 5 and 12. Find the length of the hypotenuse.
solution:
Using the Pythagorean theorem: a² + b² = c²
5² + 12² = c²
25 + 144 = c²
169 = c²
c = 13

title: Volume of Cone
description: Find the volume of a cone with radius 6 cm and height 8 cm
solution:
The volume of a cone is V = (1/3)πr²h
V = (1/3)π(6)²(8) = (1/3)π(36)(8) = 96π cubic cm

title: Basic Trigonometric Identity
description: Verify the identity: sin²θ + cos²θ = 1 for θ = 30°

title: Law of Cosines
description: In triangle ABC, a = 7, b = 10, and C = 60°. Find side c.
solution:
Using the Law of Cosines: c² = a² + b² - 2ab cos(C)
c² = 7² + 10² - 2(7)(10)cos(60°)
c² = 49 + 100 - 140(1/2) = 149 - 70 = 79
c = √79 ≈ 8.89

title: Double Angle Formula
description: Use the double angle formula to find sin(2θ) if sin(θ) = 3/5 and θ is in the first quadrant
solution:
sin(2θ) = 2sin(θ)cos(θ)
Given sin(θ) = 3/5, and θ in first quadrant
cos(θ) = √(1 - sin²(θ)) = √(1 - 9/25) = √(16/25) = 4/5
sin(2θ) = 2(3/5)(4/5) = 24/25

title: Mean and Standard Deviation
description: Find the mean and standard deviation of the dataset: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10

title: Probability with Dice
description: What is the probability of rolling two dice and getting a sum greater than 9?
solution:
Favorable outcomes for sum > 9: (4,6), (5,5), (5,6), (6,4), (6,5), (6,6)
That's 6 outcomes out of 36 total possible outcomes.
Probability = 6/36 = 1/6

title: Normal Distribution
description: In a normal distribution with mean 100 and standard deviation 15, what percentage of values lie within one standard deviation of the mean?
solution:
By the empirical rule (68-95-99.7 rule), approximately 68% of values in a normal distribution lie within one standard deviation of the mean.
This means 68% of values lie between 100 - 15 = 85 and 100 + 15 = 115.

title: Prime Factorization
description: Find the prime factorization of 360

title: Greatest Common Divisor
description: Find GCD(48, 72) using the Euclidean algorithm

title: Modular Arithmetic
description: Find the remainder when 2⁵⁰ is divided by 7
solution:
Find pattern of powers of 2 mod 7:
2¹ ≡ 2 (mod 7)
2² ≡ 4 (mod 7)
2³ ≡ 1 (mod 7)
Pattern repeats every 3 powers.
50 = 3 × 16 + 2
So 2⁵⁰ ≡ 2² ≡ 4 (mod 7)

title: Matrix Multiplication
description: Multiply the matrices: [2 1; 3 4] × [5 0; 1 2]

title: Matrix Determinant
description: Find the determinant of the 2×2 matrix: [3 5; 2 4]

title: Eigenvalues
description: Find the eigenvalues of the matrix A = [4 -2; 1 1]
solution:
Find eigenvalues from det(A - λI) = 0
det([4-λ -2; 1 1-λ]) = (4-λ)(1-λ) - (-2)(1) = λ² - 5λ + 6 = 0
(λ - 2)(λ - 3) = 0
Eigenvalues: λ₁ = 2, λ₂ = 3

title: First-Order Linear ODE
description: Solve the differential equation: dy/dx + 2y = e^x
solution:
This is a first-order linear ODE: dy/dx + P(x)y = Q(x)
P(x) = 2, Q(x) = e^x
Integrating factor: μ(x) = e^∫2dx = e^(2x)
Solution: y = (1/μ)∫μQ dx = (1/e^(2x))∫e^(2x)·e^x dx = (1/e^(2x))∫e^(3x) dx
= (1/e^(2x))·(e^(3x)/3) + C/e^(2x) = e^x/3 + Ce^(-2x)

title: Separable ODE
description: Solve: dy/dx = xy/(1+x²)
solution:
Separate variables: dy/y = x dx/(1+x²)
Integrate both sides: ∫dy/y = ∫x dx/(1+x²)
ln|y| = (1/2)ln(1+x²) + C
|y| = e^C√(1+x²)
y = A√(1+x²) where A = ±e^C

title: Permutations and Combinations
description: How many ways can 5 people be arranged in a row? How many ways can 3 be chosen from the 5?
solution:
Arrangements (permutations): P(5,5) = 5! = 120 ways
Choosing 3 from 5 (combinations): C(5,3) = 5!/(3!2!) = 10 ways

title: Binomial Theorem
description: Expand (x + 2)⁴ using the binomial theorem

title: Pigeonhole Principle
description: If 11 people are in a room, prove that at least two people have birthdays in the same month
solution:
By the Pigeonhole Principle: if n pigeons are placed in m pigeonholes and n > m, then at least one pigeonhole contains more than one pigeon.
Here: 11 people (pigeons) and 12 months (pigeonholes).
Wait - this is incorrect! With 11 people and 12 months, it's possible each person has a different birth month.
However, if we had 13 people and 12 months, then by the pigeonhole principle, at least two would share a birth month.

title: Truth Tables
description: Construct a truth table for the logical expression: (P ∧ Q) → (P ∨ Q)
solution:
P | Q | P∧Q | P∨Q | (P∧Q)→(P∨Q)
T | T |  T  |  T  |     T
T | F |  F  |  T  |     T
F | T |  F  |  T  |     T
F | F |  F  |  F  |     T
The expression is always true (tautology).

title: Logical Equivalences
description: Prove that ¬(P ∧ Q) is equivalent to (¬P ∨ ¬Q) using logical equivalences
solution:
This is De Morgan's Law. We can prove it with a truth table:
P | Q | P∧Q | ¬(P∧Q) | ¬P | ¬Q | ¬P∨¬Q
T | T |  T  |   F    | F  | F  |   F
T | F |  F  |   T    | F  | T  |   T
F | T |  F  |   T    | T  | F  |   T
F | F |  F  |   T    | T  | T  |   T
The columns for ¬(P∧Q) and ¬P∨¬Q are identical, proving equivalence.

title: Mathematical Induction
description: Prove by induction that 1 + 2 + 3 + ... + n = n(n+1)/2
solution:
Base case (n=1): 1 = 1(1+1)/2 = 1 ✓
Inductive step: Assume true for n=k: 1+2+...+k = k(k+1)/2
Show true for n=k+1: 1+2+...+k+(k+1) = (k+1)(k+2)/2
LHS = k(k+1)/2 + (k+1) = (k+1)[k/2 + 1] = (k+1)(k+2)/2 = RHS ✓
By mathematical induction, the formula holds for all positive integers n.
